title: SB 1.18.38-41 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 24-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: ओम अज्ञानति मिरान्धस्य ज्ञानान्जनिषलाकया चक्षुरुन्मीलितं येनातस्मै श्री गुरवे नमः
नमाओमिष्णु पाधाया कृष्णप्रेष्ठाय भूतले श्रीमते भक्ति वेदान्त स्वामिन्नितिनामिने
नमस्ते सारस्वते देवे गवरवाणी प्रचारिने निर्विशेश शुन्यवादी पाश्चात्यदेशतारिने जाय श्री कृष्ण चैतन्या प्रभूनित्यानन्दा श्री अद्वैत गदाधरा श्रीवासाधी गवरभक्त वृन्दा

Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Deviim Saraswatim Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from four verses 38, 39, 40 and 41 of the 18th chapter of the first canto of Sriman Bhagavatam.
The 38th verse.
The meaning of this verse is
Thereafter, when the boy returned to the hermitage, he saw a snake on his father's shoulder, and out of his grief he cried very loudly.
This boy has not even seen what has happened.
He just heard from his playmates.
And immediately his reaction was,
How deadly!
How dare the king insult my father!
What does he think of himself?
Watch my power!
Now I am going to teach him a lesson!
And he became extremely angry, immediately cursed the king to die in seven days.
So this was completely impudent on his part to have cursed the king like that.
So he saw the snake on his father's shoulder after having cursed the king already.
And he began to cry very loudly, realizing what a great mistake he had done.
So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says,
The boy was not happy because he committed a great mistake and he wanted to be relieved of the burden on his heart.
By crying.
A small boy has made a very, very big mistake.
He is realizing his mistake, but it's too late.
So after entering the hermitage and seeing his father in that condition, he cried loudly so that he might be relieved.
But it was too late.
The father regretted the whole incident.
That will be described in the later verses.
39th verse
Sava Angiraso Brahman Shrutva Suta Vilapanam Unmilya Shanakair Netre Drishtva Chamse Mruthoragam
The meaning of this 39th verse.
O Brahmanas!
Now who is addressing this?
O Brahmanas!
It is Suta Goswami who is addressing the sages of Naimisharanya while describing this incident.
The rishi who was born in the family of Angira Muni.
This rishi refers to Shamika Rishi, whose ashram Pariksit had entered, searching for water.
And whose son was Sringi.
So this rishi, that is Shamika Rishi,
was born in the family of Angira Muni.
A very glorious dynasty or lineage of Brahmanas.
Hearing his son crying, gradually opened his eyes and saw the dead snake around his neck.
This rishi was sitting in trance in meditation when Pariksit entered the ashram.
So he could not properly, he could not receive the king.
He could not offer him any hospitality.
He was not conscious of his external surroundings.
He was deep in trance.
So when he heard the sound of his son crying, loudly crying,
he gradually opened his eyes, that is coming out of trance.
And he saw the dead snake around his neck.
Now what is his reaction?
That is described in the next verse.
The fortieth verse.
Visrjya tamcha papracha vatsakasmadhi rodhisi
kenavate apakritam ityuktasa nyavedayat
The meaning of this fortieth verse.
He threw the dead snake aside, Visrjya,
and asked his son why he was crying,
whether anyone had done him any harm.
On hearing this, the son explained to him what had happened.
So the rishi is hearing from his son, what happened, why are you crying?
So the boy explained what all happened.
In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says,
the father did not take the dead snake on his neck very seriously.
He just threw away the snake and did not take it very seriously.
Who has done this? Why has he done this?
Why this dead snake around my neck?
He never thought anything very seriously wrong had happened by that snake.
That snake being placed on his neck.
He simply threw it away.
Actually, there was nothing seriously wrong in Maharaj Pariksit's act.
But the foolish son took it very seriously.
And being influenced by Kali, he cursed the king.
And thus ended a chapter of happy history.
With the cursing of Maharaj Pariksit,
the Brahmanical power is lost because of misuse.
And then with the downfall of the Brahmanas,
gradually all the other sections of the society will fall down.
And thus the whole society becomes degraded.
The human society.
And it is definitely the influence of Kali.
This is the beginning of Kali Yuga.
So the influence of Kali.
Kali means irreligion personified.
The friend of irreligion.
Adharma bandhu.
So Kali is meant for spreading irreligion
among
the people of this Kali Yuga.
The forty-first words.
nishamya shaptam atad arham narendram
sa brahmano na atmajam abhyanandat
aho bata amho mahad adhyate krutham
alpi yasi droha
urur dhamo dhritah
The meaning of this forty-first verse.
The father heard from his son
that the king had been cursed,
although he should never have been condemned,
for he was the best amongst all human beings.
When Shamika Rishi heard from his son,
that the king was cursed,
he understood that
just for a very minor mistake,
the king was condemned to death.
This is one important point to note
that always the punishment for a mistake
should be in proportion to the
degree of the mistake that is committed.
That means a severe punishment
for very big blunders
and small punishment for minor mistakes.
There has to be some
consideration like this
always that is there
in punishing somebody.
The Rishi did not congratulate his son,
but on the contrary began to repent saying,
alas, what a great sinful act
was performed by my son.
He was awarded heavy punishment
for an insignificant offense.
He refers to the king.
The king was awarded heavy punishment
for an insignificant offense.
Death sentence
or death punishment,
punishment by being condemned to die
by snake bite,
is a very, very, very, very heavy punishment.
And that too, who is being punished like that?
The emperor of the world,
who is the Rajarishi,
who is the protector of all the citizens,
who was able to keep away
such a king,
such a righteous,
glorious,
wonderful,
full of wonderful qualities,
such a king
is being condemned to death.
It's a heavy punishment
for an insignificant mistake.
So in the purport,
Srila Prabhupada explains,
the king is the best of all human beings.
He is the representative of God
and he is never to be condemned
for any of his actions.
So king means
he is meant to rule over the citizens
unless he himself
is the best of all human beings.
He cannot really rule over the citizens.
So he himself is qualified,
qualified,
exceptionally qualified.
And not only that,
in the very culture,
he is the representative of God.
Because
God is the real controller of everyone.
The supreme lord, Krishna,
he is the supreme controller.
He is the supreme controller.
But
he has his representatives
and particularly in human society,
he has his
the king as
his representative.
So such a personality
is never to be condemned
for any of his actions.
In other words,
the king can do no wrong.
This is the Vedic injunction.
The king is never to be condemned.
The king is never to be
considered as
acting wrongly.
If
he is
acting as the representative of God
and he is ruling according to the
Vedic injunctions.
Now here is
an example given by Srila Prabhupada.
The king may order hanging of a culprit's son of a Brahmana,
but he does not become sinful for killing a Brahmana.
Shastras say Brahmana should never be killed.
But the king,
in exceptional cases,
when the son of a Brahmana misbehaves,
or deserves to be punished by
capital punishment,
then the king
can give that punishment
to a
somebody who is deserving such a punishment.
And in that case,
the king does not incur
the sin for killing a Brahmana.
Further, Srila Prabhupada says,
even if there is something wrong with the king,
he is never to be condemned.
So,
what to speak of a good and pious king
like Maharaj Pariksit?
So,
the king is trained to become a Rajarshi,
and a Rajarshi or a great saint,
he is never to be condemned
the way
Shringi treated this
great Maharaj Pariksit.
So, the instruction of the Vedas is,
the king is called Narendra
or Naradeva,
and he is the best amongst the human beings.
So, he should not be condemned like this.
For a minor mistake,
he may be given some
very minor punishment,
but never such a
grave punishment
or a severe punishment.
For a minor mistake,
that is completely wrong.
I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
